Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Testing the hypothesis of an orbital forcing of southwestern North America climate over the past 500,000 years
Award.AbstractNarration:
Climate scientists have long documented the strong control of Earth's orbital variations on the waxing and waning of the ice ages. Thirty years ago, an iconic climate record from Devils Hole, Nevada, seemed to suggest that Great Basin the climate of the Great Basin of the western United States was out of step with the orbital rhythm, warming after glacial periods before what would be expected from changes in the Earth's orbit. Now new evidence places Great Basin climate variations back in synchrony with orbital variations, and shows that climate warmed and cooled with the amount of solar radiation reaching the northern Hemisphere during summer over the last 175,000 years. Radiometrically-dated stalagmites from Great Basin caves have the potential extend the record back to 500,000 years before present. These cave deposits record variations in climate in a broad region over and upwind of the cave sites. As such, they are ideally suited to test for an orbital control on Great Basin climate, and will allow comparison to sea surface temperature records in the Pacific Ocean, and to the Devils Hole calcite record. This project will also facilitate long-term climate projections for the southwestern United States based on known future orbital variations.

The overarching hypothesis that will be tested in the course of this project is that southwestern paleoclimatic change was paced by Milankovitch (orbital) forcing, through changes in northern hemisphere summer insolation altering atmospheric circulation dynamics over the northeastern Pacific Ocean region. The research team will generate high-resolution oxygen isotope analyses of precisely-dated stalagmites from caves across the Great Basin region, and determine whether or not oxygen isotope variations align with variations in northern hemisphere summer insolation over the past half million years. Oxygen isotopic analyses will be carried out at the University of Nevada Las Vegas, and uranium disequilibrium dating at the University of New Mexico. The research team will include several students from both lead institutions as well as an undergraduate-serving institution, Cornell College (Iowa). The researchers and students will also create cave educational materials for sharing with local caving groups and governmental agencies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The controls on orbital-scale climate variability in the Western United States has been a topic of considerable interest. In this project, we have developed a long paleoclimate record spanning several hundred thousand years from cave calcite deposits in Nevada. Our results show that the amount of incoming solar radiation (called insolation) reaching the northern hemisphere has driven climatic variations over the last several hundred thousand years.

Our data showed that there is a nearly one-to-one relationship between the oxygen isotopic values of speleothem calcite – interpreted as a combined moisture source and temperature proxy of winter precipitation – and northern hemisphere summer insolation at 650N latitude, the so-called Milankovitch

forcing. We concluded that Milankovitch forcing is the principal control knob on Great Basin paleoclimate on long time scales.

We showed that the likely control on this climatic change was changes in Arctic sea ice, which responds strongly to the insolation variations. Interestingly, climate in Nevada lagged behind the insolation forcing by a few thousand years, suggesting that Nevada responds to changes elsewhere in the climate system, likely the Arctic.

We also documented that exceptionally cold winters (e.g. during Marine Isotope Stage 5d ~110,000 years ago) are possible in the absence of any ice sheet forcing and moderately high CO2 concentrations. This observation indicates that ice sheet extent and greenhouse gas concentration variations are weaker forcings than those mediated through changes in extent of Arctic sea-ice and snow extent.

 This project has also shown a much more detailed history of climatic change over the past 11,700 years, a period known as the Holocene. The Holocene climatic changes show a gradual warming after ice sheets decayed to small sizes, then three millennia of pronounced droughts in the Great Basin. Climate was mostly cooler and wetter over the last four thousand years. The implications of this research is that future warming in the western United States is likely to be associated with aridification and greater stress on water resources.

This strong coupling between climate and insolation provides us with the ability to forecast natural climate variations for millennia into the future. Climate projection from known future insolation variations suggests that the Great Basin is likely to remain in a warm and dry climate state for the next 55,000 years. Any additional warming from anthropogenic climate change will be superimposed on the natural warming trend, resulting in a "double-whammy" of heating in Nevada on millennial timescales. Finally, results from our study were cited in the Proclamation that established Basin and Range National Monument in Nevada.

This project has been a truly collaborative effort.  This and related projects have allowed us to participate in the broader paleoclimate effort to advance climate science, formally and informally.  As a result, our group has built a solid reputation, internationally, for doing precise and high-resolution climate work.  The data from the Great Basin are some of the longest, continuous and high-resolution continental climate records available.  They will form part of the large-scale climate high-resolution proxy circuit needed to understand climate teleconnections.
